results.title: Blaise Cendrars at the Morgan: A Modern Match of Poetry and Painting
results.abstract: A travelogue in verse, rich with Sonia Delaunay’s art  pyrotechnics, is the centerpiece of one of the most eye-opening shows of the summer.

multimedia.caption: Detail of Blaise Cendrars and Sonia Delaunay-Terk’s “The Prose of the Trans-Siberian and of Little Jeanne of France,” 1913.
multimedia.copyright: Blaise Cendrars/Succession Cendrars/Pracusa 20230412; via The Morgan Library & Museum

results.title: Secret No More: Louis Armstrong Center Amplifies Satchmo’s Vision
results.abstract: New jazz and exhibition spaces, and an inaugural show curated by Jason Moran, feature the trumpeter’s “wonderful world” in full, collaged onto the walls.

multimedia.caption: Large circular vitrines inside the new Louis Armstrong Center hold artifacts from Armstrong’s 60,000-piece archive, including 700 tapes that were once housed miles away at Queens College. Jason Moran has curated the first permanent exhibition, “Here to Stay.”
multimedia.copyright: Ike Edeani for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Large circular vitrines inside the new Louis Armstrong Center hold artifacts from Armstrong’s 60,000-piece archive, including 700 tapes that were once housed miles away at Queens College. Jason Moran has curated the first permanent exhibition, “Here to Stay.”

results.title: What to Do in New York City in August
results.abstract: Looking for something to do in New York? Catch the comedian Ali Wong at the Beacon, or enjoy a silent movie at MoMA.

results.title: ‘Barbenheimer’ Isn’t a Contest. But if It Were, Which Film Would Win?
results.abstract: It’s been an epic matchup, but it’s time to declare a victor. We devised nine super-scientific tests to determine whether “Barbie” or “Oppenheimer” rules.

multimedia.caption: “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” both address issues of life, death and fashion.
“Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” both address issues of life, death and fashion.
“Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” both address issues of life, death and fashion.

results.title: ‘Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem’ Review: Superfly’s Revenge
results.abstract: This time around, the four kung-fu-fighting old masters of the sewers dream of having a normal life with the humans. But not if Ice Cube can help it.
des_facet: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (Movie)

results.title: ‘The Notebook’ Musical to Land on Broadway in the Spring
results.abstract: The adaptation of the popular Nicholas Sparks romance novel, with music and lyrics by Ingrid Michaelson, had a well-reviewed run last year in Chicago.

multimedia.caption: “The Notebook” premiered last fall at the Chicago Shakespeare Theater, with Joy Woods and Ryan Vasquez among the actors playing the star-crossed lovers. The Broadway cast has yet to be announced.

results.title: The Dance of Too-Hot Summer? Melt Into the Pinegrove Shuffle.
results.abstract: Garrett Lee, with an assist from DJ Khaled, fills a cultural hole with his floppy, hypnotic TikTok dance — still going strong in a sad, cathartic way.

multimedia.caption: Garrett Lee in Salisbury, Mass., where he lives. Lee’s dance, the Pinegrove Shuffle, has become a viral TikTok hit. “I put a lot of hips into it,” he said.
multimedia.copyright: Tony Luong for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Garrett Lee in Salisbury, Mass., where he lives. Lee’s dance, the Pinegrove Shuffle, has become a viral TikTok hit. “I put a lot of hips into it,” he said.

results.title: ‘Passages’ Review: A Toxic Ménage
results.abstract: In Ira Sachs’ latest wince-inducing romance, Tomas (Franz Rogowski) has wedged himself into a love triangle with Ben Whishaw and Adèle Exarchopoulos.

results.title: A New Subject for a Veteran Documentary Maker: Herself
results.abstract: The French director Claire Simon was making a movie about a Paris hospital when she found out she had cancer. So she became a character in her own film.

multimedia.caption: In her new film, “Our Body,” Claire Simon said she was concerned by questions like, “How does our civilization treat the female body?,” and, “What is the relationship between the body and words?”
multimedia.copyright: Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: In her new film, “Our Body,” Claire Simon said she was concerned by questions like, “How does our civilization treat the female body?,” and, “What is the relationship between the body and words?”

results.title: As Objects Fly Onstage, Stars Become Part of the Audience’s Show
results.abstract: Disrupting a celebrity may now be the ultimate concert souvenir. No pop star wants to be unsafe, but some are increasingly making themselves part of the crowd.

multimedia.caption: A sampling of the types of objects that have recently landed onstage. Clockwise from top left: a vape pen (Drake), a teddy bear (Harry Styles), a bra (Drake again), a cellphone (Bebe Rexha), a wheel of Brie (Pink) and ashes (also Pink).
multimedia.copyright: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photos via Getty Images

multimedia.caption: A sampling of the types of objects that have recently landed onstage. Clockwise from top left: a vape pen (Drake), a teddy bear (Harry Styles), a bra (Drake again), a cellphone (Bebe Rexha), a wheel of Brie (Pink) and ashes (also Pink).
multimedia.copyright: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photos via Getty Images

results.title: Jason Aldean’s ‘Try That in a Small Town’ Hits No. 1
results.abstract: The country star’s song, now a culture war battleground, is his first all-genre chart topper. The K-pop group NewJeans’ new album edged out the “Barbie” soundtrack on the Billboard 200.

results.title: Review: An American Opera Gets the Attention It Needs Abroad
results.abstract: Anthony Braxton’s “Trillium X,” part of a sweeping cycle of operas that began in the 1980s, finally premiered in Prague.

results.title: The Playwright Who Changed the Face of American Theater
results.abstract: In this excerpt from “August Wilson: A Life,” the playwright, on the cusp of stardom, is polishing off his latest play, “Fences,” at the O’Neill writers’ conference.

multimedia.caption: August Wilson in 2005. He once called the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center a place where writers developing new work “can fail and your life won’t disappear.”
August Wilson in 2005. He once called the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center a place where writers developing new work “can fail and your life won’t disappear.”

results.title: ‘Air Bud: World Pup’ Keeps Winning Fans for the 1999 World Cup Stars
results.abstract: The 2000 movie used the franchise’s furry hero along with members of the actual U.S. women’s team to reimagine the penalty shootout that led to the win.

results.title: Myron Goldfinger, 90, Architect of Monumental Modernist Homes, Dies
results.abstract: His houses, which dot the Hamptons and other parts of the New York region, include a residence featured in “The Wolf of Wall Street.”

multimedia.caption: A house built in 1981 for Fred Jaroslow, the chief operating officer of Weight Watchers, gained prominence in 2013 when it was the setting for a debauched party in the film “The Wolf of Wall Street.”

results.abstract: I’m a technology correspondent for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.

results.abstract: In this tender and funny documentary, Nira Burstein films her parents in their house in Queens without making excuses about their unsettled lives.

results.title: Australia Will Return Looted Sculptures to Cambodia
results.abstract: A centuries-old Buddhist sculpture was taken from a rural area in Cambodia nearly 30 years ago. It was later sold with two other statues to the National Gallery of Australia.

multimedia.caption: Bronze sculptures of Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara Padmapani and attendants, which will be returned from Australia to Cambodia.

results.abstract: Carrie and Aidan play house. Miranda and Charlotte get back to work.

results.title: Bidding for Simon & Schuster Draws to a Close
results.abstract: The move to acquire the publisher, one of the five largest in the country, comes after the government blocked a deal last year on antitrust concerns.
results.byline: By Benjamin Mullin, Elizabeth A. Harris and Lauren Hirsch

multimedia.caption: Paramount has again accepted bids for Simon & Schuster, one of the largest publishers in the country, months after an initial deal was blocked in court.
Paramount has again accepted bids for Simon & Schuster, one of the largest publishers in the country, months after an initial deal was blocked in court.

results.title: Roger Sprung, Banjo Virtuoso of N.Y.C. Folk Scene, Dies at 92
results.abstract: The “godfather” of progressive bluegrass, he grew up in New York, honed his skills in the mountains and flourished in Greenwich Village in the ’60s.

multimedia.caption: Roger Sprung and his longtime collaborator Hal Wylie performing in 2010 in Greenwich Village. His career had flourished in the Village scene of the 1960s.
Roger Sprung and his longtime collaborator Hal Wylie performing in 2010 in Greenwich Village. His career had flourished in the Village scene of the 1960s.

results.title: Lois Libien, Who Found a Readership With Household Tips, Dies at 87
results.abstract: As a journalist she covered issues affecting women, then turned to writing about housekeeping in handbooks and a syndicated newspaper column.

multimedia.caption: Lois Libien in 2017. Her witty advice column and book delved into the details of household maintenance with practical tips, like how to create a homemade grease remover.
Lois Libien in 2017. Her witty advice column and book delved into the details of household maintenance with practical tips, like how to create a homemade grease remover.

results.title: Striking Actors Are Turning to Cameo for Extra Cash
results.abstract: Others are using the service, through which fans can pay for personalized videos, to engage with followers while not publicly promoting work.

results.title: Streep and Clooney Lead Donation Campaign for Striking Actors
results.abstract: The stars, joined by celebrities like Matt Damon and Oprah Winfrey, helped raise more than $15 million over the past three weeks.

results.title: Why Nina Simone Was Always Ahead of Her Time
results.abstract: A recently unearthed live version of “Blues for Mama,” written by Simone and Abbey Lincoln in the 1960s, took on domestic abuse in a momentous way.

multimedia.caption: Nina Simone, the pianist, jazz singer and civil rights activist who died in 2003, addressed domestic violence in the song “Blues for Mama,” which she wrote with Abbey Lincoln.
Nina Simone, the pianist, jazz singer and civil rights activist who died in 2003, addressed domestic violence in the song “Blues for Mama,” which she wrote with Abbey Lincoln.

results.title: ‘Spamalot’ Revival to Open on Broadway This Fall
results.abstract: The new production, directed by Josh Rhodes, had a brief run at the Kennedy Center in Washington in May. Casting has not yet been announced.

multimedia.caption: James Monroe Iglehart and other cast members in the Kennedy Center production. A Broadway cast has yet to be announced.

results.title: Read Your Way Through Hanoi
results.abstract: Hanoi, long a city of storytellers, has been devastated and reborn time and time again. Nguyễn Phan Quế Mai guides readers through the literature that has played a part in that renewal.

results.title: A.I.’s Inroads in Publishing Touch Off Fear, and Creativity
results.abstract: The technology has the potential to affect nearly every aspect of how books are produced — even the act of writing itself.
results.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter

multimedia.caption: Artificial intelligence is already being used in some aspects of the book business, and has the potential, in time, to touch nearly the whole process.
Artificial intelligence is already being used in some aspects of the book business, and has the potential, in time, to touch nearly the whole process.

results.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Miles Davis’s Electric Period
results.abstract: Navigate the trumpeter’s snaky, endless grooves with picks from Flying Lotus, Cindy Blackman Santana and Terence Blanchard, among other musicians, writers and critics.

results.title: ‘Sex Is a Huge Part of a Character’s Life.’ Especially in ‘Passages.’
results.abstract: The three stars of Ira Sachs’ new movie — Franz Rogowski, Ben Whishaw and Adèle Exarchopoulos — discuss the graphic film’s approach to sexuality and intimacy.

multimedia.caption: In “Passages,” a narcissistic movie director, played by Franz Rogowski, left, has an affair with a schoolteacher, played by Adèle Exarchopoulos.
In “Passages,” a narcissistic movie director, played by Franz Rogowski, left, has an affair with a schoolteacher, played by Adèle Exarchopoulos.
